The Carolingian Renaissance: Now that I have formally established myself as Emperor of the Romans, it is time to improve my internal affairs. The greatest minds, scholars, poets, artists, writers, and whatever else shall be welcomed into my courts from across the land, and reforms shall be enacted throughout the Empire. Together, we shall create a true Carolingian Renaissance.
My first action must be to open my courts to the greatest scholars available. It must be known that my Empire is a place of learning.
An Italian man has arrived, claiming he comes from a grammar school in Ivrea. He wishes to serve in the Carolingian Court.
A gifted man of relatively low birth has arrived from the monastery of Fulda. He wishes to serve in the Carolingian Court.
His birth matters not. Welcome him!
Remove this common rabble from my court!
A gifted scholar from the House of Pisa in Italy has arrived at the court. He wishes for his knowledge of scripture to be utilised for the Empire.
A remarkably talented Anglo-Saxon has arrived from York, in the Kingdom of Northumbria. His knowledge and wit are outstanding.
He is exactly what we need
In my conquest of the Kingdom of Lombardy, one scholar in particular piqued my interest. Upon my request, he has arrived at my court, despite the bad blood between the Franks and Lombards.
Lombard or not, he is welcome
No damn Lombards in my court
A man by the name of Odo has arrived in Aachen, claiming to be a great architect hailing from Armenia. He promises buildings of much grandeur.
A young but promising youth raised in my retinue has pledged his loyalty and wishes to serve in the Carolingian Court.
